newsitem.title: UK: INTERVIEW - ASDA set to outperform.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - ASDA set to outperform.

text.p: British supermarket group ASDA Plc should continue to outperform the market, chief executive Allan Leighton told Reuters in a telephone interview.
"Do I believe that we can continue to outperform the industry? Yes I do," Leighton said.

He said the company expected to refurbish around five stores and open five new ones this year, which will create "about 3,500-4,000 jobs and the distribution centre...we'll be close to 5,000 jobs this year, probably."

ASDA's sales from existing stores rose 9.2 percent in the year ending May 3 as pretax profits before exceptionals jumped 16 percent to 353.7 million stg, and it paid out a total dividend of 3.05 pence per share.
"I would be expecting us to outperform not just on sales but operating profit too," he said, but added that achieving such strong sales growth "becomes more and more difficult".
Leighton said that last year, ASDA's gross margins were flat and its prices became cheaper as optimising margin mix allowed the company to invest in price.
He said operating margins were "about flat".

The company said in a statement that industry figures showed it was eight percent cheaper than its major competitors, and Leighton said: "Provided the gap is maintained or increased versus our competitors that's the key measure for me."
Leighton said planning permission for new stores was "getting tougher," but stressed a point of difference for ASDA was the size of its superstores and location in out-of-town sites.
He said he felt ASDA's clothing business, sold under the "George" brand set up with George Davis who worked with Next, could be twice the current size.
Clothing sales at existing stores rose 28 percent. Leighton said there was "still a lot to do...to deliver this kind of performance consistently but I think we will".
He said volume sales of clothing in the group's best stores were on similar levels to shops in the high street but operating costs were half.
"If I can sort the supply chain out...you can then generate a quality offer...at 20 percent of the price. That is a set of economics that nobody else can emulate," Leighton said.
He said another area where the company was focusing efforts and had opportunities was in the change towards eating take-away and ready-made meals.
"We have the biggest Indian take-away business in the UK and we have the biggest fish-and-chip take-away business in the UK," he said.
Leighton added that in groceries, "there's still a lot of innovation that you can do".
ASDA had "lots to do", particularly in beers, wines and spirits and frozen foods.
"The only way in a very mature marketplace that you can outperform and generate real return is you've got to innovate faster than anybody else," he said.
